importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the Tel Aviv soccer derby was canceled due to violent riots, marking a significant incident in Israeli public order and sports culture.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The incident occurred during the scheduled Tel Aviv derby match, highlighting a critical moment in sports and public safety dynamics in Israel.

keyTakeAways: The Tel Aviv soccer derby between Hapoel and Maccabi was canceled due to violent riots and public disorder, with injuries reported among civilians and police.
Police cited the risk of endangering human life as the reason for canceling the match, citing pyrotechnics and smoke grenades thrown by fans.
Hapoel criticized the police response, claiming it resembled preparing for war rather than managing a sporting event.
Nine people were arrested, and 16 were detained for questioning, with 12 civilians and three police officers injured.
This incident follows previous security concerns involving Maccabi fans, including a ban in England for a Europa League match and violent scenes in Amsterdam.
UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer condemned the England police decision to ban Maccabi fans, emphasizing that the police should not restrict fan attendance without due process.
Downing Street acknowledged concerns about the Tel Aviv incident and expressed interest in understanding the situation with Israeli authorities.

namedEntities.name: Tel Aviv
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A city in Israel, site of the soccer derby between Hapoel and Maccabi.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The location where the derby match was held, central to the incident of public disorder and fan violence.

namedEntities.name: Hapoel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A professional soccer team based in Tel Aviv, one of the rivals in the derby.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the competing teams whose fans were involved in the riots, leading to criticism of police actions.

namedEntities.name: Maccabi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A professional soccer team based in Tel Aviv, rival to Hapoel in the derby.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The other team in the derby; its fans were also involved in violent scenes, contributing to the cancellation of the match.

namedEntities.name: Israel Police
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The law enforcement agency responsible for public order in Israel.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The entity that canceled the match due to public disorder and injuries, raising questions about its response to fan violence.

namedEntities.name: Bloomfield Stadium
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A stadium shared by Hapoel and Maccabi in Tel Aviv.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The venue where the match was scheduled to take place, now closed due to violence and public disorder.

namedEntities.name: Aston Villa
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An English football club, venue for a previous Europa League match involving Maccabi.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The host team in a previous match where Maccabi fans were banned due to security concerns.

namedEntities.name: West Midlands Police
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The police force in England responsible for banning Maccabi fans from attending a game at Aston Villa.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The English authorities who made a prior decision to ban Maccabi fans, sparking controversy and international concern.

namedEntities.name: Keir Starmer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He publicly criticized the ban on Maccabi fans in England and expressed concern about fan safety and discrimination.

namedEntities.name: Ajax (Dutch football team)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Dutch football club, site of a previous violent incident involving Maccabi fans.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The opponent in a match in Amsterdam where Maccabi fans were involved in violence, linking to prior security concerns.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Tel Aviv soccer derby between Hapoel and Maccabi was canceled due to violent riots and public disorder, with police reporting injuries to 12 civilians and three officers, and nine arrests. Fans reportedly threw pyrotechnics and smoke grenades, prompting authorities to cancel the match citing danger to human life. Hapoel criticized the police response, claiming it resembled a military confrontation. This incident follows prior security issues involving Maccabi fans, including a ban in England for a Europa League match at Aston Villa and violent events during a game against Ajax in Amsterdam. UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer condemned the English ban, emphasizing the need for fan safety and inclusivity, while acknowledging the seriousness of the Tel Aviv incident and expressing a desire to understand the situation with Israeli authorities.
title: Tel Aviv Soccer Derby Canceled by Police Due to 'Violent Riots'
